p: Mileski et al. [ 34] reported the antioxidant activity of methanol, ethanol, and aqueous extracts obtained from aerial parts and inflorescences of F. macedonica. The DPPH results demonstrated that extract derived from the inflorescences (in the range of 490–1170 μg/mL) were more active than the extract obtained from the aerial parts (630–1810 μg/mL). This evidence was confirmed, also, in an ABTS test. The antioxidant potential of the crude extract and four fractions of F. carduchorum aerial parts, at two vegetative stages, were analyzed by Golfakhrabadi et al. [ 35]. The highest DPPH radical scavenging activity was found for flower crude extract, with an IC 50 of 0.49 mg/mL, followed by fruit crude extract (IC 50 of 0.62 mg/mL) and flower methanol fraction (IC 50 of 0.68 mg/mL).
